Mike,

I've never seen it. I am interested, but ultimately we are looking f=
or a
solution that will work outside of Eclipse. We are working on an open =
source
library, and we can't know what IDE/build environment other contribu=
tors
will be using.

Maybe if I get something worked up they would consider=
 making it a
supplemental part of JUnit. In the worst case, I'll make a dis=
tro of my code
available on SourceForge.

Landon

On Fri, Nov 20, 2009 at 1=
1:20 AM, Forsberg, Mike <
mike.forsberg@...> wrote:

>
>
> =
Have you looked at how eclipse handles AssertEquals of two Strings.
>
> Not=
 sure if this is a JUnit core functionality or not. But eclipse
> highlight=
s how the two strings differ.
>
> Just wondering if you've ever seen this f=
unctionality... I'll send screen
> shots if not.
>
> Big Mike
>
> From: jun=
it@yahoogroups.com <junit%40yahoogroups.com> [mailto:
> junit@yahoogroups.c=
om <junit%40yahoogroups.com>] On Behalf Of Sunburned
> Surveyor
> Sent: Fri=
day, November 20, 2009 12:06 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com <junit%40yahoog=
roups.com>
> Cc: Martin Davis; Martin Davis
> Subject: [junit] Gathering an=
d displaying supplemental information about
> test failures.
>
>
> I have a=
 question about the options for gathering and displaying
> supplemental inf=
ormation about test failures. Please allow me to
> illustrate my question w=
ith a simple example.
>
> I've got a class called Coordinate that represent=
s a point in a 3D
> coordinate system. I've overloaded the toString method =
of this class
> to write out the X, Y, and Z values of the coordinate in a =
simple
> String. Now I want to test my toString method using JUnit.
>
> If =
the Coordinate.toString test method fails (because the string was
> not con=
structed in the correct format) I would like to provide the
> programmer ru=
nning the test with a copy of the incorrect string, since
> it provides val=
uable clues about what is broken with the method under
> test. I typically =
do this by placing System.err.println statements in
> my test method. Howev=
er, I realize that using System.err.println isn't
> the most portable or el=
egant way to provide this information to the
> programmer executing the tes=
t.
>
> What I really want is a GUI that allows the programmer to select a
>=
 failed test from a list of failed tests, and then to view supplemental
> t=
est data I provide him/her.
>
> I was thinking I could do this by completin=
g the following tasks:
>
> - Implementing the RunListener interface in JUni=
t.
> - Create an extension of Exception that could contain a HashMap of
> s=
imple parameters and that would be passed to the constructor of a
> Failure=
 object from within a test.
> - Creating Failure objects in my tests that c=
ontain the supplemental
> failrure data.
> - Passing these failure objects =
to my RunListener implementaiton.
> - Creating a FailureProcessor class tha=
t displays a GUI with the
> information in my RunListener implemenation to =
show the programmer
> executing my tests the supplemental failure data as d=
escribed above.
> (FailureProcessor would be an interface so that you could=
 do different
> things with the supplemental failure data, not just show it=
 in a GUI.)
>
> Before I begin this work, I wanted to ask if there was a be=
tter way to
> do this. I know I could use a logging framework from within m=
y test
> method, but I really want to work within the JUnut framework, not
=
> outside of it. I also want a nice little GUI, not a log file.
>
> How are=
 other programmers handling instances when they want to display
> supplemen=
tal data on failed tests? Does my approach sound reasonable?
>
> The Sunbur=
ned Surveyor
>
